How Is Schr√∂dinger‚Äôs Cat Both Alive and Dead? A famous thought experiment by a brilliant Nobel laureate who also happened to be a notorious pedophile. In quantum mechanics terms, the cat‚Äôs ability to be in an ambiguous state of both alive and dead until it‚Äôs observed (i.e. when someone opens the box) is referred to as quantum indeterminacy or the observer‚Äôs paradox. The paradox states that an event or an experiment‚Äôs observer affects its outcome. In this case, whomever is performing this hypothetical experiment can affect whether the cat remains in an unknown state or they can open the box and know if the cat is dead or alive with 100 percent certainty. The experiment also points out when the resolution of possibilities occurs. The experiment is intended to make people ask themselves if it was logical for the observation to trigger the answer. After all, wouldn‚Äôt the cat be either dead or alive even if we never open the box? ‚Äú Spending most of his life as an academic with positions at various universities, Schr√∂dinger, along with Paul Dirac, won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1933 for his work on quantum mechanics, the same year he left Germany due to his opposition to Nazism. In his personal life, he lived with both his wife and his mistress which may have led to problems causing him to leave his position at Oxford. Subsequently, until 1938, he had a position in Graz, Austria, until the Nazi takeover when he fled, finally finding a long-term arrangement in Dublin, Ireland, where he remained until retirement in 1955, and where he is said to have pursued several sexual relationships with minor girls. Walter Moore, author of the definitive biography "Schr√∂dinger, Life and Thought" published in 1989, said that the physicist's attitudes towards women was essentially that of a white male supremacist. The biography more or less seemed to downplay and even romanticize his clearly abusive and unacceptable behavior , and instead describes him as just having a "Lolita complex." The girls he abused were as young as 12. #quantummechanics #schroedinger #lolitasexaffairs #pedophile

üåü Science Legend of the Day: Edward Witten üåü On this day, we celebrate the remarkable achievements of Edward Witten, one of the most influential theoretical physicists of our time. His pioneering work has significantly advanced our understanding of the universe. üî¨ Key Contributions: String Theory and M-Theory: Witten's groundbreaking work in string theory and the proposal of M-theory have been pivotal in unifying various versions of string theory. M-theory suggests the existence of 11 dimensions, providing a deeper insight into the fabric of our universe. Fields Medal Winner: In 1990, Witten made history as the first physicist to receive the Fields Medal, often regarded as the "Nobel Prize of Mathematics," for his profound impact on mathematical physics. Topological Quantum Field Theory: His research has opened new pathways in both theoretical physics and pure mathematics, particularly in the study of manifolds and knot theory. üìö Interesting Facts: Interdisciplinary Influence: Witten‚Äôs work is a perfect blend of physics and mathematics, demonstrating how the two fields can complement and enhance each other. Collaborative Spirit: His wife, Chiara Nappi, is also a theoretical physicist, and together they have made significant contributions to the field. Educational Impact: Known for his ability to convey complex ideas with clarity, Witten has inspired countless students and researchers to pursue careers in theoretical physics. üåå Legacy and Inspiration: Edward Witten's contributions continue to shape the landscape of modern theoretical physics. His theories not only push the boundaries of our understanding but also inspire future generations to explore the fundamental questions of our universe. Join us in celebrating Edward Witten and his extraordinary contributions to science! üå† #ScienceLegend #TheoreticalPhysics #StringTheory #MTheory #Mathematics #EdwardWitten #Inspiration #STEM #didyouknow

üí´ Professor üí´ Maciej Dunajski, a professor at the University of Cambridge and former student of Stephen Hawking, has solved a fundamental mathematical problem that has been open for 120 years. üï∞ üí• Professor Hawking üí• mentored Professor Dunajski for many years, and the Polish mathematician learned from one of the greatest minds of all time. Inspired by his mentor, Professor Dunajski began his research on black holes. ‚è≤ After years of work, while skiing in Austria, Professor Dunajski had a breakthrough. He solved a problem that neither his mentor nor any other mathematician in history had been able to solve. üí° He solved the problem of metrizability, which is the study of distance on something other than a plane. We study this with the Pythagorean Theorem and Euclidean geometry. Professor Dunajski figured out how to study distances on the surface of spheres and other curved manifolds! ‚èè ‚≠ê His theorem turned out to be of fundamental importance to Einstein's General Theory of Relativity and the theory of Black Holes. Today, the Polish professor is an icon at his college. He literally has an office in the most prestigious part of Clare College, and everyone there knows him. He is also one of the closest collaborators of Professor Roger Penrose. ‚≠ê üèÜ Together with the 2020 Nobel laureate, they are looking for an answer to the fundamental question of creating a Grand Unified Theory. The professor is the only person I know who combines mathematics and physics at such a high level. A man who was written off in school is now one of the most outstanding mathematicians at the fourth best university in the world and the best university in Europe. üë®üî¨ Only the scientist he met on his way discovered the power of his mind. #mathematics #blackholes #breakthrough #UniversityofCambridge #StephenHawking #GrandUnifiedTheory

‚ÄúI was sitting in my chair at the patent office in the city of Bern when suddenly a thought crossed my mind: If a person is in free fall, he will not feel their own weight. This simple thought had a profound impact on me. It led me towards a theory of gravity, a revelation.‚Äù These sentences were the first words that Einstein penned when introducing the theory of general relativity. A theory that had a profound influence on our understanding of the physical universe and became a cornerstone of scientific research. Its impact was so deep that even after over a century since its presentation in 1915, new results are still being derived from this theory. For example, the Nobel Prize in Physics in 2017 was awarded for the observation of gravitational waves, a prediction of general relativity. Likewise, the Nobel Prize in Physics in 2020 was awarded for the prediction and observation of black holes, another outcome of general relativity. The 2011 Nobel Prize in Physics was also awarded for the discovery of the gravitational redshift effect, which is related to general relativity. You can see that a simple question and the theory that followed it had such a profound impact on science that even more than a century later, scientists are still receiving Nobel Prizes for it. It's unclear who first had such a question in their mind. It's possible that this question had crossed the minds of thousands before Einstein, but he was the first to diligently seek an answer to it. My friend, if a question has also crossed your mind, ask and ask, keep asking until you find an answer that satisfies you. If you can‚Äôt find someone to answer your question, take matters into your own hands and study, study until you find an answer to your question. The greatest scientific theories have not arisen from complex calculations and experiments, but rather from the simplest and most fundamental questions. Many of the issues that seem self-evident in schools and universities are not so obvious when we approach them with a questioning mind. However, remember that science is a systematic approach with these stages: observation, questioning, hypothesis, experiment, analysis, conclusion. Observation and questioning are only two stages of the scientific method, and a subject only becomes physics when it reaches the final stage through the scientific method. Amalie Emmy Noether (1882 - 1935) Emmy Noether, as she was more commonly known, was a German mathematician described as the most important woman in mathematics history. Emmy developed significant theories in math and physics, including algebraic invariants and the ring theory! Her Noether‚Äôs Theorem forged a link between symmetries in nature and the conservation of energy, momentum, and electric charge. Generations of physicists have relied on her theorem to understand everything from subatomic particles to black holes. Essentially, her work framed the way we look at modern physics. Having completed her dissertation in 1907, she worked unpaid for 11 years at 2 institutes before her credentials were finally recognized for her to be paid as a lecturer. Emmy was a scholar on the same plane as Madame Curie; a mathematician who crafted new systems which continue to be relevant in the fields of theoretical physics and mathematics. We are delighted to welcome Mr. David Brandolini to the CLRC. Mr. Brandolini is currently completing a Master's degree at the University of Dallas as a Quintilian Fellowship recipient in Humanities with a focus in Classical Education. For the last eight years, he taught a variety of subjects across middle and high school for a classical charter school network, including great books seminar courses, writing, history, and natural science. Mr. Brandolini will be teaching the following classes this year: - American Literature (https://lnkd.in/gF-gaaFH) - U.S. Government (https://lnkd.in/gdFMNWZw) - Middle School Nature of Science (https://lnkd.in/g2JNuhfb) Nature of Science introduces middle school students to the main branches of science ‚Äî biology, chemistry, and physics. Students are awakened to the natural things already a part of their experience and develop the habit of attending to the nuances of nature. They are encouraged to wonder at the pervasive mystery in nature, and seek the deepest reasons "Why?". Students are introduced to many basic concepts like metabolic systems, mass, density, inertia, projectile motion, optics, atomic theory, etc. within the context of the exciting discoveries made by people like Aristotle, Euclid, Faraday, Lavoisier, Newton, Bohr, Galileo, and Maxwell. #clrconline #naturalscience #classicaleducation #onlineschool #homeschool
